trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus topics (Python) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus topics (Python) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Service Bus topics and subscriptions from Python.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Service Bus topics and subscriptions from Python.

trans-unit.source: How to Use Service Bus topics and subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to Use Service Bus topics and subscriptions

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Service Bus topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Python and use the <link><linkText>Python Azure package[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Python and use the <link><linkText>Python Azure package[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating topics and subscriptions, creating subscription filters, sending messages to a topic, receiving messages from a subscription, and deleting topics and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about topics and subscriptions, see the <link><linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title></link> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information about topics and subscriptions, see the <link><linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title></link> section.

trans-unit.source: Note: If you need to install Python or the Python Azure package[], please see the Python Installation Guide.
trans-unit.target: Note: If you need to install Python or the Python Azure package[], please see the Python Installation Guide.

trans-unit.source: How to create a topic
trans-unit.target: How to create a topic

trans-unit.source: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with topics.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceBusService object enables you to work with topics.

trans-unit.source: Add the following near the top of any Python file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Service Bus:
trans-unit.target: Add the following near the top of any Python file in which you wish to programmatically access Azure Service Bus:

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Replace mynamespace, sharedaccesskeyname, and sharedaccesskey with your actual namespace, shared access signature (SAS) key name, and value.
trans-unit.target: Replace mynamespace, sharedaccesskeyname, and sharedaccesskey with your actual namespace, shared access signature (SAS) key name, and value.

trans-unit.source: You can obtain the values for the SAS key name and value from the Azure management portal connection information, or in the Visual Studio Properties window when selecting the Service Bus namespace in Server Explorer (as shown in the previous section).
trans-unit.target: You can obtain the values for the SAS key name and value from the Azure management portal connection information, or in the Visual Studio Properties window when selecting the Service Bus namespace in Server Explorer (as shown in the previous section).

trans-unit.source: create\_topic also supports additional options, which enable you to override default topic settings such as message time to live or maximum topic size.
trans-unit.target: create\_topic also supports additional options, which enable you to override default topic settings such as message time to live or maximum topic size.

trans-unit.source: The following example sets the maximum topic size to 5 GB, and a time to live value of 1 minute:
trans-unit.target: The following example sets the maximum topic size to 5 GB, and a time to live value of 1 minute:

trans-unit.source: How to create subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to create subscriptions

trans-unit.source: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Topic subscriptions are also created with the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages delivered to the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions are named and can have an optional filter that restricts the set of messages delivered to the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: Note: Subscriptions are persistent and will continue to exist until either they, or the topic they are associated with, are deleted.
trans-unit.target: Note: Subscriptions are persistent and will continue to exist until either they, or the topic they are associated with, are deleted.

trans-unit.source: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter
trans-unit.target: Create a subscription with the default (MatchAll) filter

trans-unit.source: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.
trans-unit.target: The MatchAll filter is the default filter that is used if no filter is specified when a new subscription is created.

trans-unit.source: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.
trans-unit.target: When the MatchAll filter is used, all messages published to the topic are placed in the subscription's virtual queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a subscription named 'AllMessages' and uses the default MatchAll
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a subscription named 'AllMessages' and uses the default MatchAll

trans-unit.source: filter.
trans-unit.target: filter.

trans-unit.source: Create subscriptions with filters
trans-unit.target: Create subscriptions with filters

trans-unit.source: You can also define filters that enable you to specify which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can also define filters that enable you to specify which messages sent to a topic should show up within a specific topic subscription.

trans-unit.source: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.
trans-unit.target: The most flexible type of filter supported by subscriptions is SqlFilter, which implements a subset of SQL92.

trans-unit.source: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.
trans-unit.target: SQL filters operate on the properties of the messages that are published to the topic.

trans-unit.source: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, see the <link><linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression[]</linkText><title></title></link> syntax.
trans-unit.target: For more details about the expressions that can be used with a SQL filter, see the <link><linkText>SqlFilter.SqlExpression[]</linkText><title></title></link> syntax.

trans-unit.source: Filters can be added to a subscription by using the create\_rule method of the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Filters can be added to a subscription by using the create\_rule method of the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: This method allows you to add new filters to an existing subscription.
trans-unit.target: This method allows you to add new filters to an existing subscription.

trans-unit.source: Note: Since the default filter is applied automatically to all new subscriptions, you must first remove the default filter or the MatchAll will override any other filters you may specify.
trans-unit.target: Note: Since the default filter is applied automatically to all new subscriptions, you must first remove the default filter or the MatchAll will override any other filters you may specify.

trans-unit.source: You can remove the default rule by using the delete\_rule method of the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: You can remove the default rule by using the delete\_rule method of the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: The example below creates a subscription named HighMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom messagenumber property greater than 3:
trans-unit.target: The example below creates a subscription named HighMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a custom messagenumber property greater than 3:

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named LowMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a messagenumber property less than or equal to 3:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the following example creates a subscription named LowMessages with a SqlFilter that only selects messages that have a messagenumber property less than or equal to 3:

trans-unit.source: When a message is now sent to mytopic, it is always delivered to receivers subscribed to the AllMessages topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the HighMessages and LowMessages topic subscriptions (depending on the message content).
trans-unit.target: When a message is now sent to mytopic, it is always delivered to receivers subscribed to the AllMessages topic subscription, and selectively delivered to receivers subscribed to the HighMessages and LowMessages topic subscriptions (depending on the message content).

trans-unit.source: How to send messages to a topic
trans-unit.target: How to send messages to a topic

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application must use the send\_topic\_message method of the ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus topic, your application must use the send\_topic\_message method of the ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to mytopic.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send five test messages to mytopic.

trans-unit.source: Note that the messagenumber property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this determines which subscriptions receive it):
trans-unit.target: Note that the messagenumber property value of each message varies on the iteration of the loop (this determines which subscriptions receive it):

trans-unit.source: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).
trans-unit.target: Service Bus topics support a maximum message size of 256 MB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 MB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a topic but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a topic.

trans-unit.source: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This topic size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: How to receive messages from a subscription
trans-unit.target: How to receive messages from a subscription

trans-unit.source: Messages are received from a subscription using the receive\_subscription\_message method on the ServiceBusService object:
trans-unit.target: Messages are received from a subscription using the receive\_subscription\_message method on the ServiceBusService object:

trans-unit.source: Messages are deleted from the subscription as they are read when the parameter peek\_lock is set to False.
trans-unit.target: Messages are deleted from the subscription as they are read when the parameter peek\_lock is set to False.

trans-unit.source: You can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the parameter peek\_lock to True.
trans-unit.target: You can read (peek) and lock the message without deleting it from the queue by setting the parameter peek\_lock to True.

trans-unit.source: The behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: The behavior of reading and deleting the message as part of the receive operation is the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: If the peek\_lock parameter is set to True, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: If the peek\_lock parameter is set to True, the receive becomes a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When Service Bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete method on the Message object.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete method on the Message object.

trans-unit.source: The delete method marks the message as being consumed and removes it from the subscription.
trans-unit.target: The delete method marks the message as being consumed and removes it from the subscription.

trans-unit.source: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages
trans-unit.target: How to handle application crashes and unreadable messages

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock method on the Message object.
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock method on the Message object.

trans-unit.source: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the subscription and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause Service Bus to unlock the message within the subscription and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the subscription, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (for example, if the application crashes), then Service Bus unlocks the message automatically and makes it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the subscription, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (for example, if the application crashes), then Service Bus unlocks the message automatically and makes it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the MessageId property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: How to delete topics and subscriptions
trans-unit.target: How to delete topics and subscriptions

trans-unit.source: Topics and subscriptions are persistent, and must be explicitly deleted either through the Azure management portal or programmatically.
trans-unit.target: Topics and subscriptions are persistent, and must be explicitly deleted either through the Azure management portal or programmatically.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to delete the topic named mytopic:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to delete the topic named mytopic:

trans-unit.source: Deleting a topic also deletes any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.
trans-unit.target: Deleting a topic also deletes any subscriptions that are registered with the topic.

trans-unit.source: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.
trans-unit.target: Subscriptions can also be deleted independently.

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to delete a subscription named HighMessages from the 'mytopic' topic:
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to delete a subscription named HighMessages from the 'mytopic' topic:
